'''Rissi Palmer''' (born August 19, 1981) is an American [[country music]] artist. Palmer debuted in 2007 with the single "Country Girl", which made her the first African-American woman to chart a country song since [[Kathy Bee]] in 1988.<ref name=goddesscouturenews>[https://goddesscouturenews.com/society-spotlight/kathy-bee-trailblazing-black-female-country-singer-who-charted-history-on-billboard/]. October 19, 2007.</ref> "[[Country Girl (Rissi Palmer song)|Country Girl]]" peaked at No. 54 on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Hot Country Songs]] charts, and served as the lead-off single to her [[Rissi Palmer (album)|self-titled debut album]], which also produced the Top 100 hit "Hold On to Me". Also in 2008, Palmer covered "[[No Air]]", an [[R&B]] hit originally performed by [[Jordin Sparks]] and [[Chris Brown (American singer)|Chris Brown]]. She is also the host of [[Apple Music]] Country's show ''Color Me Country Radio with Rissi Palmer''.<ref name="music.apple.com">{{Cite web|url=https://music.apple.com/us/curator/color-me-country/1500977601|title = Color Me Country on Apple Music|via=[[Apple Music]]}}</ref>

==Biography==
Palmer was born in [[Sewickley, Pennsylvania|Sewickley]],<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.pantagraph.com/entertainment/article_a6471251-2c4c-5126-9f36-10b0f934e354.html |title=Welcome to nginx |access-date=September 11, 2012 |archive-date=September 11, 2012 |archive-url=https://archive.today/20120911124759/http://www.pantagraph.com/entertainment/article_a6471251-2c4c-5126-9f36-10b0f934e354.html |url-status=dead }}</ref> a suburb of [[Pittsburgh]], Pennsylvania, and lived there until moving with her family to [[Eureka, Missouri|Eureka]], Missouri, a suburb of [[St. Louis]], at the age of 12.<ref>
{{cite AV media |people = Rissi Palmer, Jon Anthony |date = October 25, 2007 |title = Highway 16 Driver's Ed |medium = radio |publisher  = XM Radio |location = Nashville, TN <!--|format = broadcast |access-date = October 25, 2007--> |time = 9:00 EDT }}</ref> Her parents were natives of [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]]. Palmer has said her mother, who died when Palmer was seven, "was a huge [[Patsy Cline]] fan", while her father loved musicians such as [[Johnny Cash]], [[Dolly Parton]], [[Chaka Khan]], and [[Carlos Santana|Santana]].<ref name=phillyinquirer>[http://www.philly.com/inquirer/entertainment/20071021_A_country_singer_who_bucks_custom.html "A country singer who bucks custom"] by Dan DeLuca, The Philadelphia Inquirer, October 21, 2007. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071023182731/http://www.philly.com/inquirer/entertainment/20071021_A_country_singer_who_bucks_custom.html |date=October 23, 2007 }}</ref> Palmer said she knew from a young age that she wanted to sing. As a child, she sang on a [[Mickey Mouse Club]]-like local television sponsored group called ''Team 11''. At age 16, she performed country music at the [[Arkansas]] State Fair.<ref name=phillyinquirer/>

When she was 19, R&B producers [[Jimmy Jam|James "Jimmy Jam" Harris III]] and [[Jimmy Jam|Terry Lewis]] offered her a deal on their [[Flyte Tyme Records]]. Palmer rejected the deal because she said they wanted to turn her "twangy" country style into a "pop/soul hybrid." As she said, "I love R&B and urban music, but it wasn't what I wanted to do. I knew I wouldn't be happy doing that."<ref name=wallstreetjournal>"To Be Young, Gifted and Country: Rissi Palmer Finds Her Place On the Country Music Charts" by Ethan Smith, The Wall Street Journal, September 28, 2007, Page W3.</ref> After that, Palmer sang jingles for [[Barbie]] commercials, recorded music for the ''[[Dance Fever]]'' television show, and competed on ''[[Star Search]]'', all while trying in vain for seven years to land a [[Nashville, Tennessee|Nashville]] recording contract.<ref name=phillyinquirer/>

In 2004, Rissi was one of several African-American artists featured in the documentary, ''Waiting in the Wings: African-Americans in Country Music'', highlighting the contributions of African-Americans in country music while questioning why few have found success in the genre.<ref name=www.cmt.com>{{Cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/news/1485407/documentary-highlights-african-americans-in-country-music/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200218171006/http://www.cmt.com/news/1485407/documentary-highlights-african-americans-in-country-music/|url-status=dead|archive-date=February 18, 2020|title=Documentary Highlights African-Americans in Country Music|website=Cmt.com|access-date=January 13, 2022}}</ref> The documentary aired on CMT on February 27, 2004.

Rissi performed at the 2nd Annual Black Girls Rock ceremony, along with Jean Baylor (formerly of Zhane) and Emily King in 2007.<ref name=www.essence.com>{{Cite web|url=https://www.essence.com/celebrity/black-girls-rock-ten-years-ago/|title=Black Girls Rock! What The Annual Celebration Of Black Magic Looked Like 10 Years Ago|website=Essence.com|date=October 26, 2020 |access-date=January 13, 2022}}</ref>

Palmer was at the [[2008 Democratic National Convention]] in [[Denver]] on August 26, 2008, and supported [[Barack Obama]]. She was also an invited performer at the [[White House]] for the National Tree Lighting Ceremony in December 2008.<ref name="http://www.allaccess.com">{{Cite web|url=https://www.allaccess.com/net-news/archive/story/49863/rissi-palmer-to-perform-for-pres-bush-at-national-|title=Rissi Palmer To Perform For Pres. Bush At National Tree Lighting|website=Allaccess.com|access-date=January 13, 2022}}</ref>

Rissi starred in and hosted a Travel Channel show called ''Rissi Palmer's Country''.<ref name=www.allaccess.com>{{Cite web|url=https://www.allaccess.com/net-news/archive/story/53509/rissi-palmer-to-debut-new-music-show-on-travel-cha|title=Rissi Palmer To Debut New Music Show On Travel Channel|website=Allaccess.com|access-date=January 13, 2022}}</ref> The show was set to explore the music of a given city, and the pilot episode focused on the blues in Chicago. The pilot aired on February 28, 2009, but was not taken to series.

After a year and a half long legal dispute, Palmer parted ways with 1720 Entertainment in 2009.

==Music career==
===Debut album: ''Rissi Palmer'' (2007–2008)===
In 2006, [[Starbucks Entertainment]] distributed a four-song [[extended play]] that put Palmer among the top 5 best-selling country artists on [[iTunes]].<ref name=msnbc>[https://www.today.com/popculture/black-woman-rissi-palmer-country-rarity-wbna21307946 "As black woman, Rissi Palmer is country rarity"] [[Associated Press]]. October 19, 2007.</ref> Palmer was also featured in a 2005 [[CMT (American TV channel)|CMT]] documentary about African-Americans and country music.<ref name=wallstreetjournal/>

Palmer's debut album, ''[[Rissi Palmer (album)|Rissi Palmer]]'', was released on October 23, 2007, by 1720 Entertainment. Palmer co-wrote nine of the 12 tracks.<ref name=msnbc/> She was the featured artist on [[Yahoo]]! Music's "The New Now," which highlights talented newcomers, from October 17 through November 21, 2007.<ref>[http://www.countryhound.com/News/Article.aspx?p=544&AspxAutoDetectCookieSupport=1 "Rissi Palmer Is The New Now"] by Stephen L. Betts, October 10, 2007. Retrieved October 22, 2007. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080213011002/http://www.countryhound.com/News/Article.aspx?p=544&AspxAutoDetectCookieSupport=1 |date=February 13, 2008}}</ref> The album produced two chart singles for Palmer in "[[Country Girl (Rissi Palmer song)|Country Girl]]" and "Hold On to Me," which peaked at number 54 and number 59 on the U.S. ''Billboard'' Hot Country Songs chart, respectively.

In 2008, Palmer released a new single, a cover of [[Jordin Sparks]] and [[Chris Brown (American singer)|Chris Brown]]'s "[[No Air]]."  The song debuted at number 58 and eventually reached number 47, becoming her first Top 50 single on the [[Hot Country Songs]] chart. It was included on a reissue of her debut self-titled album later that year.<ref name="cst">{{cite web |url=http://www.countrystandardtime.com/news/newsitem.asp?xid=1936 |title=Rissi Palmer comes up with 'No Air' |access-date=July 21, 2008 |website=Countrystandardtime.com }}</ref>

Palmer also released a Christmas single in late 2008, "[[Grown Up Christmas List]]," before Palmer ultimately parted ways with her record label.

===''The Back Porch Sessions'' EP (2015)===
On March 18, 2014, Rissi launched a [[Kickstarter]] campaign to fund the creation of her follow-up to her self-titled debut, a five-song EP entitled ''The Back Porch Sessions''.<ref name=www.kickstarter.com>{{cite web|url=https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/rissipalmer/executive-produce-my-new-album-the-back-porch-sess/description|title=Executive Produce my new album The Back Porch Sessions Vol.1|website=Kickstarter.com|access-date=January 13, 2022}}</ref> The project was produced by Grammy Award-winning producers Shannon Sanders and Drew Ramsey, who also produced on her first album. Rissi has described the sound of this EP as "Southern Soul", a mix of country, soul, R&B, with a little gospel. The title of the project is a nod to her great-grandmother's porch in Summerville, Georgia, where Palmer says she began singing as a child.<ref name=www.rollingstone.com1>{{Cite magazine|url=http://www.rollingstone.com/music/features/rissi-palmer-on-soulful-comeback-its-scary-and-empowering-20150625?page=3|title=Page 3 of Rissi Palmer on Soulful Comeback: 'It's Scary and Empowering' | Rolling Stone|magazine=[[Rolling Stone]]|date=September 24, 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924180134/http://www.rollingstone.com/music/features/rissi-palmer-on-soulful-comeback-its-scary-and-empowering-20150625?page=3|access-date=January 13, 2022|archive-date=September 24, 2015}}</ref> ''The Back Porch Sessions'' was released through Rissi's label, Baldilocks LLC on May 26, 2015.

The project has received positive reviews from critics. Music journalist Jewly Hight wrote: "Palmer has been describing her Back Porch Sessions EP, released in late May, as Southern soul, but there's more in the mix than a single descriptor can contain: jazz-relaxed neo-soul sensuality, streamlined country-pop song structure, down-home nostalgia, rootsy instrumental textures, honeyed melisma and a more expansive vocal palette than she's displayed in the past".<ref name=www.nashvillescene.com>{{cite web|url=http://www.nashvillescene.com/nashville/sunday-night-soul-feat-rissi-palmer-and-jason-eskridge/Event?oid=5177099|title=Sunday Night Soul feat. Rissi Palmer & Jason Eskridge|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150725140644/http://www.nashvillescene.com/nashville/sunday-night-soul-feat-rissi-palmer-and-jason-eskridge/Event?oid=5177099|access-date=January 13, 2022|archive-date=July 25, 2015}}</ref> The EP has been featured in publications such as Rolling Stone, ''People Magazine'', and on Perez Hilton's popular website.

===''Revival'' (2019)===
On October 22, 2019, Rissi released the full-length album, ''Revival''.<ref name="http://news.theurbanmusicscene.com">{{Cite web|url=http://news.theurbanmusicscene.com/2019/10/rissi-palmer-to-release-new-album-revival/|title=Singer Rissi Palmer to Release New Album "Revival" on Oct. 22nd, 2019 | WATCH NEW VIDEO!|date=October 1, 2019|website=Theurbanmusicscene.com|access-date=January 13, 2022}}</ref> The album was produced by Brian Owens, Shannon Sanders, and Palmer. The first single, "Seeds", produced by Shannon Sanders, was released on October 15, 2019, along with a video directed by Emil Gallardo.{{cn|date=December 2023}} Described as a "protest song", "Seeds" was written after the murder of Michael Brown in Ferguson, MO and the video depicts images of a police shooting and an immigrant child locked in a cage. The second release was the song "Soul Message", which was featured in Rolling Stone Country's "10 Best Songs of the Week" on October 14, 2020.<ref name=www.rollingstone.com>{{Cite web|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/best-country-americana-songs-this-week-thousand-horses-898523/|title=10 Best Country, Americana Songs to Hear Now: A Thousand Horses, the Cadillac Three|first=Robert|last=Crawford|website=Rollingstone.com|date=October 14, 2019|access-date=January 13, 2022}}</ref> The third release from the album was "You Were Here (Sage's Song)", (written about a miscarriage Palmer suffered in the summer of 2019), on February 3, 2020, with an accompanying animated video.<ref name=www.guitargirlmag.com>{{Cite web|url=https://guitargirlmag.com/news/music-news/rissi-palmer-releases-powerful-video-for-you-were-here-sages-song/,%20https://guitargirlmag.com/news/music-news/rissi-palmer-releases-powerful-video-for-you-were-here-sages-song/|title=Rissi Palmer Releases Powerful Video For "You Were Here (Sage's Song)" |website=Guitargirlmag.com|date=February 5, 2020|access-date=January 13, 2022}}</ref>

''Revival'' has been described as "a potent punch of soul, rootsy R&B, and back-porch country"<ref name=www.rollingstone.com /> and Rissi's most personal work to date.<ref name=www.rissipalmermusic.com>{{Cite web|url=https://rissipalmermusic.com/bio|title=Rissi Palmer - Bio|website=Rissipalmermusic.com|access-date=January 13, 2022}}</ref> Kyesha Jennings from Indy Week says "At its core, ''Revival'' is eight tracks of pure inspiration for navigating love, racial tensions, self-acceptance, and, above all, perseverance."<ref name=www.indyweek.com>{{cite web|url=https://indyweek.com/music/features/rissi-palmer-revival-album-review|title=Rissi Palmer's "Revival" Is Pure Inspiration for Navigating Love, Racial Tensions, and Self-Acceptance|website=Indyweek.com|date=November 12, 2019 |access-date=January 13, 2022}}</ref>

=== Color Me Country Radio with Rissi Palmer ===
On August 30, 2020, ''Color Me Country Radio with Rissi Palmer'' debuted on Apple Music Country.<ref name="music.apple.com"/> The show "brings to the forefront the Black, Indigenous, and Latinx histories of country music that for too long have lived outside the spotlight and off mainstream airwaves."<ref name="music.apple.com"/> The bi-weekly show has featured interviews with artists such as [[Darius Rucker]], [[Mickey Guyton]], [[The War and Treaty]], and [[Crystal Shawanda]].<ref name="music.apple.com"/> The title of the show comes from the name of the [[Color Me Country|debut album]] of country artist [[Linda Martell]], the highest charting solo black woman on the Billboard Country Chart,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://songdata.ca/2020/10/28/how-inheritance-is-reproduced-or-how-the-country-music-industry-fails-to-address-diversity/|title=How Inheritance is Reproduced. Or, How the Country Music Industry Fails to Address Diversity|website=Songdata.ca|date=October 28, 2020 |access-date=January 13, 2022}}</ref> and the first to appear on the [[Grand Ole Opry]] in 1969.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nbcnews.com/news/nbcblk/country-music-s-reckoning-black-women-forge-their-own-path-n1243570|title = Country music's reckoning: Black women forge their own path in whitewashed industry|website=Nbcnews.com| date=October 15, 2020 }}</ref>

As an offshoot of the show, Rissi established the Color Me Country Artist Grant Fund as a partnership with Apple Music Country Host Kelly McCartney's Rainey Day Fund "to support the underrepresented voices of BIPOC artists in country music".<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://colormecountry.com/color-me-country-artist-grant-fund/|title = Color Me Country™ Artist Grant Fund|website=Colormecountry.com}}</ref> The grant will provide a micro-grant fund with cash gifts of up to $1,000. The fund was established on December 18, 2020 and One-hundred percent of the fund goes to artist grants.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://indyweek.com/music/news/rissi-palmer-color-me-country-fund/|title = Country Star Rissi Palmer on Supporting the Next Generation of Black Country Music Artists|website=Indyweek.com|date = January 12, 2021}}</ref>

In 2023, she was profiled in an episode of the PBS series [[American Masters]] entitled “In the Making”.  Her leadership of a Color Me Country day at a music festival in England was highlighted.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.pbs.org/wnet/americanmasters/in-the-making-broadcast/26250/|title = In The Making | American Masters | PBS|website = [[PBS]]|date = 24 March 2023}}</ref>

In 2024, Palmer's self-titled debut album was remastered and rereleased on streaming platforms, including three bonus tracks that were not originally included on the record.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://musicrow.com/2024/05/rissi-palmer-rereleases-2007-debut-album-on-streaming-platforms/|title=Rissi Palmer Rereleases 2007 Debut Album On Streaming Platforms|author=Lorie Hollabaugh|date=May 2, 2024|website=Music Row|accessdate=May 4, 2024}}</ref>
